title: 112_hr1638
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dollar Bill Act of 2011". Congress acknowledges that the Federal Reserve System has been delegated the power to regulate the value of US and foreign currency, but notes that the value of the US dollar has significantly decreased and become unstable. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has not provided a reliable value for the US dollar. The value of the United States dollar has become unstable and uncertain, as acknowledged by Congress. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has not produced a stable and reliable value for the dollar, leading to negative impacts on the economy, capital costs, corporate taxes, worker earnings, and public financial assets. An unstable dollar negatively impacts American workers' earnings, financial assets, pension plans, and the country's global standing. It also creates anxiety and uncertainty in financial markets and the public. SEC. 3. DIRECTIVES TO THE BOARD OF GOVERNORS OF THE FEDERAL RESERVE. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is directed to make the value of the U.S. dollar equal to the price of gold on the COMEX exchange and maintain it at that level. They are also instructed to use banking powers to ensure stable financial markets during and after the transition. Effective January 1, 2011, entities can expense 100 percent of capital investment for tax purposes in the year of investment. SEC. 5. The Congressional Budget Office will calculate the impact on Federal revenues of tax changes in this Act on a present value basis, similar to Social Security Trustees' calculations. It considers first-year expensing of capital investment and higher returns on business investments. SEC. 6. Conflict of laws provision. SEC. 6. Conflict of laws provision. SEC. 7. Removal of Federal Reserve Bank authority to pay earnings on reserves. SEC. 7. Amendment to the Federal Reserve Act removes the authority for Federal Reserve banks to pay earnings on reserves.
